item.headline: HHS4Uh_WEEK 1
item.content:
This week, you will:

  • explore a variety of topics related to families in Canada to identify topics for research and inquiry.

To Do:

Exploring the Social Sciences

Lesson Description:

In this lesson on Exploring the Social Sciences, students will delve into the intricate world of family dynamics in Canada. Through a combination of discussion, brainstorming, and the use of visual organizers, they will unravel the effects of changes in marriage and divorce legislation on individuals and families, as well as the repercussions of economic downturns on children, parents, and the elderly. The primary objective of this lesson is to empower students to identify topics for research and inquiry, gain a deep understanding of key concepts, and formulate effective questions to guide their investigative journey. 

  • Complete Exploring the Social Sciences
  • Answer all the activities for the lesson.
  • Complete Lesson 1.1 Exploring the Social Sciences Homework (Conversation)
  • Due Date: April 23

item.headline: HHS4Uh_WEEK 2
item.content:
This week, you will:

  • identify key concepts related to their selected topics.formulate effective questions to guide their research and inquiry. 
  • explore a variety of topics related to families in Canada to identify topics for research and inquiry.
  • Identify key concepts related to their selected topics.

To Do:

Social Science Theories

Lesson Description:

In this lesson on Social Science Theories offers an exciting journey into the intricate realm of family dynamics in Canada. Students will explore a range of topics related to Canadian families, such as the consequences of changes in marriage and divorce legislation on individuals and families and the impact of economic downturns on children, parents, and the elderly. The lesson aims to guide students in identifying potential research and inquiry topics, grasping key concepts, effectively recording and organizing information, and understanding the research process while fostering self-reflection and evaluation.

  • Complete Social Science Theories
  • Answer all the activities for the lesson.
  • Complete Lesson 1.2 Social Sciences Theories Homework (Observation)
  • Due Date: April 25

Learning to Research

Lesson Description:

In this lesson is designed to equip students with the essential research skills required to embark on successful academic and professional research endeavors. In this session, students will learn how to locate and select information from a diverse array of primary and secondary sources, evaluate the quality and relevance of the gathered information, uphold principles of academic integrity, and effectively communicate research findings while adhering to APA conventions for acknowledging sources. These fundamental research skills are essential for academic and professional success.

  • Complete Learning to Research
  • Answer all the activities for the lesson.
  • Complete Lesson 1.3: Learning to Research (C)
  • Due Date: April 25

item.headline: HHS4Uh_WEEK 3
item.content:
This week, you will:

  • locate and select information relevant to their investigations from a variety of primary sources and/or secondary sources.
  • record and organize information and key ideas using a variety of formats.
  • synthesize findings and formulate conclusions.  
  • demonstrate academic honesty by documenting the sources of all information generated through research.
  • clearly communicate the results of their inquiries, and follow APA conventions for acknowledging sources.
  • analyze and interpret research information.
  • use an appropriate format to communicate the results of their research and inquiry effectively for a specific purpose and audience.

To Do:

Finding the Main Idea

Lesson Description:

In this lesson is focused on developing critical research and communication skills, specifically honing the ability to find and articulate the main idea within various sources. Students will learn to locate and select information from primary and secondary sources, record and organize this information effectively, synthesize findings to draw meaningful conclusions, uphold principles of academic honesty, and clearly communicate their research results while following APA conventions for source acknowledgment. These skills are crucial for success in both academic and professional research and communication.

  • Complete Finding the Main Idea
  • Answer all the activities for the lesson.
  • Complete Lesson 1.4 - Mini- Assessment Finding the Main Idea
  • Due Date: May 2

Trends, Issues, And Challenges

Lesson Description:

In this lesson on Trends, Issues, and Challenges, students will delve into the art of analyzing and interpreting research information. They will learn how to compare results from diverse sources, extract common themes, and differentiate primary data findings from secondary source reports. Moreover, students will gain the skills to effectively communicate their research results in various formats tailored to specific purposes and audiences. This lesson equips students with vital research and communication proficiencies to understand, discuss, and address contemporary trends, issues, and challenges.

  • Complete Trends, Issues, And Challenges
  • Answer all the activities for the lesson.

item.headline: HHS4Uh_WEEK 4
item.content:
This week, you will:

  • Demonstrate your understanding of theoretical perspectives and research on various aspects of individual development.

To Do:

Unit 1 Assessment of Learning and Reflection

Lesson Description:

In this lesson, you will complete an assessment of your learning for this unit that is provided by the teacher. 

  • Complete Unit 1 Summative
  • Complete Unit 1 Reflection (Metacognition)
  • Due Date: May 2

item.headline: HHS4Uh_WEEK 5
item.content:
This week, you will:

  • demonstrate academic honesty by documenting the sources of all information generated through research.
  • use an appropriate format to communicate the results of their research and inquiry effectively for a specific purpose and audience.
  • use terms relating to families in Canada correctly.
  • clearly communicate the results of their inquiries, and follow APA conventions for acknowledging sources.
  • assess ways in which norms, values, and expectations influence individual decisions throughout the lifespan.
  • analyse the impact of social institutions on the socialization of individuals throughout the lifespan.
  • reflect on the impact of social norms, roles, and institutions on the personal level.

To Do:

Roles and Norms

Lesson Description:

This lesson focuses on understanding the roles and norms within Canadian families. It equips students with the skills to explore and research this topic while maintaining academic integrity. Students will learn to employ appropriate communication formats, utilize family-related terminology correctly, and effectively communicate their research results using APA conventions for source acknowledgment.

  • Complete Roles and Norms
  • Answer all the activities for the lesson.
  • Complete Lesson 2.1 Discussion Activity: Roles and Norms (Conversation)
  • Due Date: May 16

Norms, Roles, and Institutions

Lesson Description:

In this lesson, students will explore how social norms, values, and expectations shape the choices people make throughout their lives—such as decisions about education, careers, relationships, and identity. They will also examine the powerful role of social institutions like family, school, media, religion, and government in shaping who we are and how we behave. Through discussions, real-life examples, and reflection activities, students will gain a deeper understanding of how these social forces influence their own lives and the lives of others.

  • Complete Norms, Roles, and Institutions
  • Answer all the activities for the lesson.
